story.text: NEW YORK Malaysian airline AirAsia Bhd (AIRA.KL) is set to order 100 Airbus jetliners, increasing its existing order for single-aisle A320s, as it looks to expand its service in Southeast Asia, The Wall Street Journal reported on Wednesday, citing a person it said had knowledge of the decision. The order would be worth $6.7 billion based on list prices, the Journal said. It would mark a huge win for Airbus, majority-owned by European aerospace group EADS EAD.PA, against U.S. rival Boeing Co. (BA.N). The low-cost carrier expects to take delivery of the new planes starting in 2012, the Journal said. Earlier this year, AirAsia ordered 40 A320s and took options to buy an additional 30. An Airbus spokesman declined to comment on the report. A call to AirAsia was not immediately returned.
story.title: airasia to order more airbus a320s : report
